newsitem.title: FRANCE: Next French government faces stark Thomson choice.
newsitem.headline: Next French government faces stark Thomson choice.

text.p: The next French government faces a stark choice about the sale of a controlling stake in defence electronics group Thomson-CSF for which two final bids were made on Wednesday.

On the one hand it has an offer by electric engineering group Alcatel-Alsthom and privately-owned Dassault Industries which would make Thomson-CSF the key French defence contractor with a possible link to aerospace group Aerospatiale as well.

Already valued at 23 billion francs ($4 billion), Thomson-CSF would regroup the other companies' defence activities and become the main European defence group by sheer size. It would have a strong card to play in a European restructuring.

On the other hand the government has an offer by Lagardere Groupe, which was the preferred bidder in a previous sale attempt. It has the support of British Aerospace Plc and Germany's Daimler Aerospace but would not leave Thomson-CSF intact.

Under the Lagardere plan, British Aerospace would get indirect control over Thomson's missiles businesses through the Matra BAe Dynamics (MBD) joint venture with Lagardere's Matra Defense Espace unit.
Britain's GEC Plc has signed memoranda of understanding with both bidders after it was barred by the government from making its own bid because of national security interests.
Financial analysts have said Lagardere's alliances could help it win over Alcatel.

Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said on Wednesday evening that the government still planned to announce a decision before June 30, but the bids would be locked up until after the two-round parliamentary election of May 25 and June 1 which puts the future of French defence in the hands of the voters.
The opposition Socialist Party has made it clear that it would not continue with the privatisation of Thomson-CSF.

While they too will be faced with the need to restructure the defence industry because of falling orders and strong concentration in the U.S. industry, a Socialist government is more likely to take an active part in a restructuring involving state groups Thomson-CSF, Aerospatiale and perhaps arms maker GIAT.
Aerospatiale is currently in merger talks with combat-plane maker Dassault Aviation and is also involved in the restructuring of the Airbus plane-making consortium.
If the current centre-right coalition would win, and opinion polls give it a narrow lead over a combination of the Socialist and Communist parties, the decision is not straightforward.
The government of Alain Juppe last year prefered a bid by Lagardere over one of Alcatel because it found the first bid to have a better industrial logic.

It had to suspend the decision on the sale of Thomson SA -- which included both the Thomson-CSF stake and consumer electronics group Thomson Multimedia (TMM) -- after a public outcry and a negative Privatisation Commission advice about the sale by Lagardere of TMM to Daewoo Electronics of South Korea for a symbolic franc.

If Juppe were to stay Prime Minister after the election, the government will have to act upon the instruction of President Jacques Chirac who has said he wanted a strong French defence industry to play a leading role in a European restructuring -- which leaves both options open.
If Juppe's government were to be replaced with a new team to underline the President's commitment to a new start after the snap parliamentary, election the decision could swing either way.

With Philippe Seguin, current speaker of parliament, as Prime Minister there could be a bigger stress on the French interests and he could prefer the Alcatel bid. Alcatel has said it would negotiate with GEC and Dasa in a second stage.
If a free-marketeer such as Alain Madelin got a say in the decision there could be a preference for the more encompasing Lagardere deal which is strongly market-oriented.

And if former Prime Minister Edouard Balladur were to return to office, his preference would be somewhere between Seguin and Madelin and neither Alcatel nor Lagardere is an obvious winner. ($ = 5.790 French Francs)
